questions.text: Which of the following inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bedaquiline

Highyeild:

Bedaquiline Inhibits mycobacterial ATP SYNTHESIS Bedaquiline (BDQ) inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthase, thereby limiting energy production within mycobacterial cells. The human ATP synthase is 20,000-fold less sensitive to BDQ than the mycobacterial enzyme. It has exhibited strong bactericidal and sterilizing activity against M. tuberculosis in vitro tests and animal models by killing both rapidly multiplying as well as dormant bacilli. The MICs of BDQ are very low and similar for drug-sensitive as well as for MDR-TB and XDR-TB strains. Many non-tubercular mycobacteria and M. leprae are also inhibited in vitro.

This metabolite gets accumulated in an acidic medium and probably inhibits mycolic acid synthesis Option: D . Ethambutol MOA- inhibits cell wall synthesis

questions.text: OC pills are contraindicated in patients receiving :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rifampicin

Highyeild:

Rifampin is a powerful enzyme inducer and therefore OCPs are not given along with rifampin. Ampicillin can also produce their failure as it can impair the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens mediated by bacteria. Rifampin is a microsomal enzyme inducer—that increases several CYP450 isoenzymes, including CYP3A4, CYP2D6, CYP1A2 and CYP2C subfamily. It thus enhances its own metabolism (area under the plasma concentration-time curve is reduced by ~35%) as well as that of many drugs. Contraceptive failures have occurred. It is advisable to switch over to an oral contraceptive containing a higher dose (50 µg) of estrogen or use an alternative method of contraception

questions.correct_answer: B. Major adverse effect of pyrazinamide is hepatitis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Major adverse effect of pyrazinamide is hepatitis

Highyeild:

Pyrazinamide is a bactericidal drug. It is more active in an acidic medium and is highly lethal to intracellular bacilli as well as those present at sites of inflammation (pH is acidic at these sites). It is absorbed orally and has good penetration in CSF. It is extensively metabolized in the liver and excreted in urine. Hepatotoxicity is the most important dose-dependent adverse effect. Pyrazinamide may increase serum uric acid concentrations and decrease the efficacy of anti-gout therapy; dosage adjustments of these medications may be necessary to control hyperuricemia and gout when anti-gout medications are used concurrently with pyrazinamide.
